bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Kellihan to George W. Roosevelt, United States Consul in Brussels

msIdentifier.repository: Ministère des Affaires étrangères, Brussels, Belgium

revisionDesc.change: renamed file, inserted correct header template, corrected transcription

div1.p:
1308 Farnam Street,
Omaha, Nebraska, U.S.A.,
May 20th 1901.

George W. Roosevelt Esq.,
United States Consul,
Brussels, Belgium.

The Department of State, Washington, with whom I have had some correspondence in regard to the Congo Free State, South Africa, have referred me to you as probably being able to give me some pertinent informations desired.

I would first state that a party of American citizens, of whom I am one, have thought to go to Central Africa, provided the inducements are sufficient to warrant our going, and we would respectfully ask you for the following information:
First, the character of the timber in the timber belt along the Congo and tributaries.
Second, the character of the country as regards the production of rubber, either from natural or artificial plantations.
Third, the character of the country as to the production of sugar and cocoa, and the possibilities of educated prospectors making mineral discoveries of value.

What is the method of obtaining title to property in the Congo Free State? Would an American Corporation be subject to hostile actions at the hands of the regularly constituted authorities of the Free State.

Could you furnish us any data with regard to the profits of the trading companies now
occupying the field, the class of merchandise mostly handled, the trading regulations &c.
Thanking you kindly for your early consideration of the above requests,

I am,
Yours very truly,
(Signed) E.J. Kellihan
